In fact, basically wherever

without hitting land you

278.74.text:
And I'm going to explain

281.21.text:

282.76.text:
So, first of all we have
to know what sound is.

289.08.text:
Here we have these giant water
particles or air particles

292.70.text:
if you prefer moving
back and forth.

296.08.text:
But, you can see the
actual wave is this bit,

300.18.text:
this sort of where
they're all stuck together.

303.68.text:
That's where there's a lot
of air in a small volume

306.73.text:
so that has a high
pressure or a high density

311.65.text:
The individual air or water
particles are just oscillating

319.19.text:
It's just the oscillation of
the air particles that moves.

324.33.text:
It's called a longitudinal wave,
because the particles are moving

329.20.text:
in the same direction
as the wave is moving.

332.43.text:
It's different from say the wave
on the surface of the water.

338.27.text:
It's actually going
round and round.

339.93.text:
But, let's say the surface
appears to go up and down,

342.64.text:
but the wave is moving
horizontally.

345.37.text:
So, that's called
a transverse wave

349.04.text:
where a sound is a longitudinal
wave, the sound in the water,

352.28.text:
the sound in the
air, same stuff.

354.08.text:
It's just a compressional
wave or a longitudinal wave

362.50.text:
We can measure a few
different things about it.

364.38.text:
So, we can measure the density,
which is how many air particles

368.46.text:
or how much mass of air or
water is in a particular volume,

373.40.text:
So, you can see where
they're all crunched

376.17.text:
up together you have
a high density.

377.80.text:
Where they're all spread
apart you have a low density.

380.54.text:
We can measure the velocity
of the individual particles

383.94.text:
as they go back and forth or
we can measure the pressure,

386.86.text: which is if you compress the air

388.74.text:
or the water it tries
to fight back.

391.41.text:
And so, it-- you've got to
apply a force to compress it.

397.29.text:
So, that's the pressure,
the amount of force you have

401.22.text:
turns out that that's the
easiest thing to measure.

403.67.text:
So, the microphones that
I'm using to talk to you

406.99.text:
at the moment are
pressure devices.

410.19.text:
They measure the pressure of
the air on a little diaphragm

413.19.text:
that then wiggles back and
forth in response to that.

416.21.text:
The sensors that we use in the
ocean are called hydrophones

420.50.text:
and they're specially
designed to work well in water

424.24.text:
for reasons that I'll try
and explain in a minute.

426.67.text:
If I put one of these in
a plastic bag and stick it

428.76.text:
in the ocean it doesn't
work very well at all even

431.80.text: if the plastic bag doesn't leak.

435.21.text:
So, in order to understand
that I have

438.89.text:
to introduce a term that's
very handy to have in the back

442.53.text:
of your mind so you can trot it
out at dinner parties and things

445.19.text:
like that to impress
your friends about the--

447.94.text:
ah yes, the acoustic impedance
of water is much higher

450.65.text:
than the acoustic
impedance of air.

452.05.text:
It's a very useful
line if you want

459.33.text:
So, acoustic impedance is
the ratio of the pressure.

465.06.text:
So, that's the force
that you've got to apply

467.53.text:
to compress the particles
closer together

470.67.text:
in the high density parts
of the wave to the velocity

478.93.text:
Turns out that for
a particular medium

483.38.text:
that has a particular density,
sorry that's a Greek letter,

485.90.text: but its rho and it means--

488.03.text:
us physicists use that
all the time for density.

490.76.text:
And so, that's the density of
the material, so either air

496.79.text:
or water and this is the speed
of sound in that material.

502.85.text: So, that's what it depends on.

504.53.text:
So, if you make it denser
the impedance goes up.

507.21.text:
If you make it-- if you
increase the sound speed

509.70.text:
in the material the
impedance goes up as well.

512.49.text:
So, let's have a look
at how they compare.

514.63.text:
So, we've got air, the stuff
we're familiar with sound in,

521.08.text:
has a density of about one
kilogramme per cubic metre,

528.13.text:
Water has a density 1000
times higher than that.

532.03.text:
Sound speed in air is about
340 metres per second,

535.30.text:
depends on altitude and density
and humidity and all sorts

538.22.text:
of complicated things, but
that's a good enough number.

541.68.text:
Sound speed in water
is a lot faster.

544.02.text:
It's about four times faster, a
bit more than four times faster.

547.21.text:
So, it's about 1500
metres per second or one

549.78.text:
and a half kilometres per second
that sound travels in water.

554.57.text:
Multiply those two together,
bump, bump, we get 374.

558.52.text:
The units are named
after Lord Rayleigh,

565.71.text:
and that means 1,500,000
Rayls for water.

574.18.text:
In fact, it's 4000
times bigger in water,

579.58.text:
Now, it turns out that
if you want something--

583.26.text:
if you want to design
a sensor for example,

586.19.text:
or you want to evolve a
sensor if you're an animal,

588.21.text: if you want it to work in air,

592.98.text:
because it has a lower
acoustic impedance it means

595.87.text:
that a small pressure causes a
large motion of the particle,

600.84.text:
so you want something floppy for
your sensor that'll move easily

605.13.text:
in response to the-- to a
relatively low air pressure.

611.20.text:
You want something that
will only move a little bit

615.49.text:
in response to a high pressure
so that it matches what happens

619.48.text:
in the water otherwise it just
tries to move out of the way

622.31.text:
and it doesn't respond
to the sound wave.

627.02.text:
So, if you go swimming
you get into the water.

631.30.text:
You've got these ears, which
have evolved to work in air.

635.00.text:
They work really well in the
lower acoustic impedance we have

638.10.text:
around us here, but they're
absolutely useless in water.

642.84.text:
And consequently we think

and there's coming

the sound that sounds a

Okay, another-- well,
this is spreading loss.

Oh, this is another
good dinner party term.

728.90.text: So, you take a lump of sound,

731.31.text:
you take it from one
place to another.

734.64.text:
So, what I'm-- when I'm talking
to you the sound's coming

738.58.text: out of my mouth, which is small.

740.01.text:
It's spreading out in this room
so it's got to get quieter,

743.50.text:
because the same acoustic
energy has to spread

746.82.text:
That's called spreading loss
and there's a magic formula

749.72.text: that you don't need to know.

752.45.text:
The other way that sound
gets quieter as it goes

755.62.text: through the air or the water is

757.50.text:
that it's moving the
particles around.

760.73.text:
of friction involved
in that process.

763.03.text:
You move something with
friction it generates heat,

765.80.text:
so you lose energy
out of the sound wave

767.85.text: and you convert it to heat.

769.96.text:
That has the technical
name of absorption.

I've just written an

778.90.text:
and avoid writing absorption,

So, we have a little

So, frequency is how fast

793.22.text:
and forth how many
times a second.

So, 10 times a second, 10 hertz,
you end up with an attenuation

802.54.text: of .15 dB per kilometre in air

806.27.text:
and .01 dB per kilometre
in water.

Don't worry about what these

but this is a lot

816.92.text:
So, and as you go up in

822.08.text:
but at any frequency you always
have much less attenuation

828.90.text:
You have much less attenuation

833.27.text:
So, that's one of the
reasons that we can get sound

But, we've got to use a

the attenuation gets higher

You can't always get sound

of thousands of hertz where

And I would point out that

and that's one reason

Okay, now we get onto

922.68.text:
So, an important
thing to realise is

927.86.text:
that the ocean is
heated from the top.

933.13.text:
The Sun shines from
the top, warms it up.

936.21.text:
Okay, so when you go home
I want you get a blowtorch

939.20.text:
out of the shed, I want you
to get a saucepan of water

941.44.text:
and I want you to try and

943.91.text:
by firing the blowtorch at
the top of the saucepan.

948.64.text:
You might take a
while to do that.

950.20.text:
In fact, you might take a very,
very long time to do that.

953.24.text:
So, you'll be able to
boil the very top bit,

955.69.text:
but you won't be able
to boil the bottom

956.99.text:
and it'll probably be
stone cold when you finish

962.44.text:
And the reason it doesn't work
is because when you heat it

965.25.text:
up at the top it
gets less dense.

967.38.text:
It gets lighter and
it tries to float.

970.04.text:
So, it's already at the top
so it can't go anywhere.

972.51.text:
So, you don't get any mixing
up of the water underneath.

976.69.text:
It just stays the way it is and
that's what the ocean's like.

980.04.text:
So, it's heated at the
top, not at the bottom.

983.22.text:
That's why we have our stoves
and we set our saucepan on top

987.33.text:
of the stove okay,
right, not underneath it.

991.23.text:
So-- but the ocean's
not like that.

995.23.text:
So, it gets colder
as you go down.

996.69.text:
This is the hot part here
where the sunlight's falling.

1001.94.text: You get this layer where the--

1003.38.text:
you got a mixing process going
on, because you got waves

1006.80.text:
that mix the water vertically
in the-- at the very top.

1010.03.text:
So, you get this bit here,
which has the obvious name

1014.91.text:
of the mixed layer
right at the top.

1017.64.text:
Must have been a genius who

1021.41.text: because it's mixed by the waves.

1023.98.text:
How thick that is depends on how

1027.16.text:
and for how long
and things like that

1029.03.text:
and consequently how much
mixing's been going on.

1032.27.text:
So, the temperature is more or

1035.56.text:
And then, once you
get below the depth

1037.67.text:
at which the waves were acting,
then you get into this region

1043.74.text:
And depending on whether it's
summer or winter you get warmer

1048.89.text:
or cooler temperatures here, so
this moves up and down a bit.

1051.79.text:
So, you get this bit
here, which changes

1053.88.text:
which is called the

1056.33.text:
But, in general it just keeps

1063.96.text:
and then it tends to

1067.07.text:
And this bit down here is called

1071.19.text:
So, all these useful words

Thermo means temperature

See that's a good one to

Salinity we're not that

because the changes

And this is a very

and it really might not

What we're interested in

1103.14.text:
which sound speed increases

It increases as you

And it increases as

So, as you go down in the

The temperature affects

1124.41.text:
So, while the temperature's

down the main thermocline
the sound speed more

Once the temperature

1137.86.text:
and the sound speed

And this turns out

as what's called a

Sound likes to hang

So, here's a little

like that previous

where it is off Perth
varies a bit

If you send the sound ray off

1180.70.text:
from 1000 metres it gets
into faster and faster water

1186.11.text:
or the sound speed increases
as it gets into shallow water

1190.70.text:
and that causes what's
called refraction.

1193.10.text:
So, refraction is like if

1196.50.text:
or into the water for example,
it gets bent by a change

1201.03.text:
in the speed of light,
same deal with sound.

1204.22.text:
Wherever there's a
change in the speed

1207.00.text: of a wave it changes direction

1212.86.text:
So, turns out that it will--
the sound will refract downwards

1219.17.text: when it's in this region here.

1222.26.text:
And then, once it
gets below the minimum

1224.50.text:
in the sound speed it's
now getting into faster

1228.10.text:
and faster water again, so it

1230.68.text:
So, you get the spending affect
and it ends up following sort

1235.27.text:
of going back and forth

1241.89.text:
And all the other
rays that you send off

at other angles do

1246.01.text:
If you go steep enough,
fair enough you'll get

out of the duct and

1252.06.text:
But, sound that's caught in the

1257.69.text:
sea surface so it doesn't
scattered by these waves

1260.31.text: that are on the sea surface.

It doesn't hit the seabed,

into the sand or mud or

1269.36.text:
So, you don't lose

1271.01.text:
and also it's not

1274.95.text:
in a way except it's still

1278.59.text:
So, you get the-- you get

1284.74.text:
So, the sound can
travel a long way

1288.59.text:
with only a very small

especially if you use

1293.17.text:
so not much is getting

You've got very little

1297.44.text: it can go for a long way.

So, if you want to go

time at Cape Leeuwin

2650.77.text:
at Rottnest you can estimate

but it's not a very

2655.71.text:
because these things
are too close together

2658.75.text:
And so, you end up with
this big yellow region here,

2667.77.text:
But, unfortunately we're--
the satellite data puts it is

2672.02.text:
down there from the

2676.91.text:
So, we don't think that the

2686.96.text:
because we really don't

2689.04.text:
There's lots of things that

2692.62.text:
They do know what
made these signals.

2695.01.text:
So, this has got
to be considered

2696.54.text:
to be more reliable

If we got the range wrong

2713.98.text:

2729.38.text:
It's about-- if the

2735.10.text:
So yeah, so unfortunately
fame and fortune will have

2740.49.text:
So, that's sort of where

2750.92.text:
that I don't have is

So, remember that I've

2759.64.text:
that the Australian Transport
Safety Bureau with a whole lot

2762.81.text:
of people from--
different experts from all

2764.94.text:

2768.33.text:
that this is the

2771.24.text:
that the aircraft would be
found in, doesn't look very big

2776.55.text:
on that map but its
60,000 square kilometres.

2780.24.text:
This blue area is where
they'd like to search

2783.25.text:
if they had a lot
more resources.

2788.26.text:
where think there is some
chance the aircraft could be.

2792.70.text:
Okay, so what they're
going to do starting in--

2798.17.text:
very soon is search this
area and they will know

2802.25.text:
when they finish that whether
the aircraft is there or not.

2806.86.text:
What happens after
that we'll see.

2812.12.text:
So, that's the priority
search area.

2814.50.text:
They've-- they're
currently in the middle

2816.58.text:
of doing what's called
safety bathometric survey,

2819.43.text:
which is another good
dinner party word.

2821.66.text:
It means measure
the water depth.

2824.34.text:
So, it's measuring the shape
of the seabed very accurately

2831.95.text:
That's being done by
Fugro Survey and also by--

2835.08.text:
there's a Chinese
vessel also doing that

2841.24.text:
They're using another
sonar system I want

2844.26.text:
to briefly mention, which is
called a multi-beam sonar.

2847.04.text:
And in this case the multi-beams
are mounted on the hulls

2850.10.text:
of the ships, which means
they can travel quite quickly

2852.82.text:
and therefore they
can survey a big area

2855.47.text:
in a reasonably short
period of time

2859.52.text:
So, the purpose of that
is to do the groundwork

2864.54.text:
They're not expecting to be
able to detect the aircraft

2870.13.text:
It's not-- doesn't have
a good enough resolution,

2874.12.text:
The water's so deep they can't
detect objects at the size

2880.82.text:
A multi-beam is really the good
old fashioned echo sounder,

2886.45.text:
which sends out a pulse of sound
straight down usually and then,

2892.57.text:
times how long it takes to
get a reflection back from it.

2896.33.text:
It's just effectively a
whole lot of those pointing

2901.44.text:
So, you're steaming
along this way

2903.76.text:
and the multi-beam is looking
out sideways as you go along,

2907.86.text: so a bit like the side scan.

2909.26.text:
It's building a picture up
as the ship moves forward.

2913.29.text:
They are pretty amazing
devices these days.

2920.15.text:
They're very sophisticated
for motion correction and all

2923.32.text:
that so to compensate for the
roll and pitch of the vessel

2928.59.text:
But, they're-- they've been
around now for long enough.

2930.68.text:
They're very mature technology
and they're really good.

2936.30.text:
So, that's what they're
doing at the moment.

2940.92.text:
What they're about to do is
a wide area search underwater

2948.88.text:
So, this is actually-- they're
now going to go in and look

2951.19.text:
for the aircraft having now
measured the shape of the seabed

2957.55.text:
Fugro Survey have also got
the contract to do that.

2961.61.text:
And the good thing from
our point of view is

2963.84.text:
that it's being run out
of their Perth office.

2966.79.text:
Fugro Survey are a very
well respected company

2970.84.text: that do a lot work mainly

2972.44.text:
for the offshore oil
and gas industry.

2974.89.text:
And these guys are very good
at doing really precise things

2981.67.text:
and that's what they're
going to need to do.

2986.06.text: They're going to use two ships.

2988.87.text:
Each one will be equipped
with a deep towed system.

2992.56.text:
So, this is a picture of
the-- one of their ships.

2996.06.text:
The other one looks
almost the same,

2998.47.text:
so I didn't bother
putting in two.

3000.90.text:
Each one of them will
be fitted with one

3004.68.text:
Each of these deep towed systems
will have our good friend the

3011.79.text:
It's an old technology,
but it's still one

3014.23.text:
of the best ways there
is of finding things.

3017.12.text:
And it will also have
a multi-beam sonar.

3021.38.text:
The purpose of the
multi-beam is--

3025.11.text:
they have several purposes for
that, but they're going to--

3027.26.text:
remember that the side scan's
not very good straight down.

3030.71.text:
It's-- the geometry
is just wrong

3032.81.text: for a side scan straight down.

3034.14.text:
So, you got this little
blind spot in the middle,

3036.75.text:
so the multi-beam will be
used to fill that blind spot.

3040.66.text:
And if they do find
the aircraft then it--

3045.10.text:
or something that could be the
aircraft, then they'll use the--

3048.20.text:
go to the higher frequency
multi-beams go straight

3051.17.text:
over the top of it with the
multi-beam and they'll be able

3054.82.text:
to build up three dimensional
pictures of what's on the seabed

3057.68.text:
to a centimetre or
with 400 kilohertz,

3063.11.text:
The other piece of acoustics
that's on there is something

3069.06.text:
which is called a ultra-short
baseline acoustic position

3071.99.text:
fixing system, which is better
known for obvious reasons USBL.

3079.31.text:
The purpose of that is
you've got this thing.

3083.70.text:
That's going to be 100
metres off the seabed.

3087.20.text:
You could be in 6000 metres
of water, so it's going

3094.83.text: You're towing it behind a ship.

3096.04.text:
You're trying to go
forwards as fast as you can

3098.68.text: so that you can cover the area.

3100.85.text:
So, you're going to need about
10 kilometres of cable in order

3106.11.text:
to get it down almost
six kilometres.

3108.73.text:
And it's going to be about four
kilometres behind the ship.

3116.51.text:
Without some way of measuring
its position you have no idea

3120.57.text:
It could be-- well you might
have a vague idea where it is,

3123.32.text: but not a very good idea.

3124.75.text:
So, the USBL system is intended
to tell you exactly where it is.

3129.40.text:
So, this is how they're
going to tow it.

3131.84.text:
So, they'll have a cable with a
very large weight on it to try

3137.10.text:
and minimise the length
of cable they have to use

3139.96.text: to get down to the seabed.

3140.96.text:
The-- here they've got a two
tonne depressor and then,

3144.92.text:
the actual tow fish is on
another line that comes out.

3149.86.text:
And this is more or less
neutrally buoyant, so it just--

3153.19.text:
so the idea is that this
is going to go up and down,

3155.95.text:
because the ship is going
up and down on the surface.

3159.15.text:
And what you're trying to
do is minimise the motion

3161.57.text:
of the platform that's
towing the sonar.

3164.28.text:
So, this configuration means
that there's less coupling

3167.60.text:
of motion of that point
through to the actual tow fish

3172.20.text:
so that way you get
better imagery.

3174.85.text:
And yea, all you're going to
do is tow this thing 100 metres

3180.11.text:
above the seabed in 6000
metres of water with about 10

3189.50.text:
You don't want it-- that
number to go negative.

3194.20.text:
A quick word on ultra-short
baseline positioning fixing

3198.04.text:
systems and then we're
just about done, I think.

3201.58.text:
So, acoustic positioning,
if you want to know

3204.28.text:
where things are
underwater GPS doesn't work.

3209.34.text:
GPS signals penetrate less than
a centimetre into salt water,

3214.18.text:
so that's not going
to do you much good.

3217.21.text:
So, sound's the only
thing you can use.

3223.91.text:
but the one that they'll be
using for this is called a USBL.

3227.32.text:
The way it works,
you've got your cable

3232.54.text:
It has a thing called
a responder on it.

3234.83.text:
All that does is it sends
out a short pulse of sound

3238.36.text:
when it gets told to
by an electrical signal

3243.26.text:
That sound signal travels to a
hydrophone array on the boat,

3249.44.text:
probably built into the bottom
of the boat on Figaro's boat,

3252.31.text:
because they use these
things all the time.

3254.78.text:
And this has a number
of hydrophones in it.

3259.66.text:
in the towed pinger
locator I have no idea,

3262.28.text:
but instead of using one
hydrophone you use three

3266.90.text:
You know where they
are very accurately.

3268.42.text:
You can measure the time of
arrival difference of the signal

3272.28.text:
at the different
hydrophones and from

3274.66.text:
that you can determine the
direction of the signal.

3277.21.text:
It's done all the time in
this sort of technology.

3280.97.text:
By measuring the time it takes
from when you send the pulse

3285.14.text:
down the umbilical to when you
get the acoustic signal back,

3288.44.text:
providing you know the speed
of sound which you can work

3290.82.text:
out if you measure the
temperature and the salinity,

3293.66.text: you can work out the distance.

3295.71.text:
So, you've got direction
from the difference

3299.42.text:
of arrival times here
and you've got distance

3301.63.text:
from the overall time it
takes the signal to get there

3306.12.text:
There's fun stuff you'd have
to do in deep water to correct

3309.88.text:
for refraction, so the
bending of the sound

3313.27.text:
as the temperature
changes you go down.

3315.30.text: But, you can do all that.

3317.59.text:
So, you can find
out where it is.

3320.44.text:
And they're going to use an
inertial navigation system

3323.15.text:
as well on the vehicle which
measures the accelerations

3326.29.text:
of the vehicle and by combining
the two they think they can get

3331.53.text:
And they should know,
because that their game.

3341.76.text:
of getting geared

and China I believe, but I'm

3372.16.text:
It's not always plain

So, wait and see but

because it could be a

They might find it the

So, I'd really recommend
